top_comment.text: How the hell does a black hole just evaporate?﻿
top_comment.author: ARobs42

comments.text:
+ARobs42 hawking radiation is created on the very edge of a black hole, on 
what is known as the *event horizon*, the point after which you can't 
escape anymore. On that edge, the symmetry between particle/anti-particles 
which are constantly generated in the vacuum is broken and the black hole 
looses a little of mass.
In empty space there's a constant birth and dead of 
these particle/anti-particles pairs, but near the event horizon, one of 
them falls into the black hole, and the other one escapes, as a form of 
energy *emanating* from the black hole.
The funny thing is that this radiation is so tiny, that black holes can 
take billions upon billions of years to evaporate. Some cosmologists even 
think that the *main* chunk of the universe's history will be dedicated 
solely to the black holes.

Listen, Observation in physics is simply "interaction with instrumentation 
which is not quantum and is made of a large number of wave functions". Any 
large/complex object interacting with a quantum one is an observer - an 
eye, an ant, a rock, a grain of sand are all consisting of a large number 
of quantum elements and can be described classically. An observer is any 
sufficiently classically behaving physical system. You can be unconscious 
and breathing at the same time with no one watching you. Biophysics still 
goes on classically even though you are knocked unconscious. Or if your 
body is dead in the ground and no one sees it, it still decomposes and all 
sorts of processes go on in it that are classically described.

That's it. No need to assert the centrality of our awareness - which is an 
emergent property of physical reality - and not its foundation.

Timmahh, FYI, this is actually demonstrably *not so* - there were complex 
structures and processes that *preceded* single-cell life, let alone 
conscious life. Planets had to form and produce/receive heat before life 
even had a chance. Even if life in the universe is ancient, there was a 
time when it did not exist. It had to start somewhere, in some physical 
environment that would sustain it. Organisms didn't just _pop_into 
existence.

A picture taken by Voyager and sent to us - before any *human* sees it - is 
fully formed and specific even though the signal is light hours away from 
Earth. Voyager is not conscious. Nor are rocks, but they still form planets 
that have a specific location and speed before life even arises in that 
solar system. We can also see early stars through long range telescopes. 
Those stars formed before elements heavier than helium had a chance to 
form. There was no life at that point - yet stuff (very specific, 
measurable and beautiful stuff) was already forming.

The observer effect has *nothing* to do with consciousness - it has to do 
with interaction of matter.
I know that Consciousness tied with Quantum Mechanics is somehow a thing in 
pseudoscience. Although it may be appealing to someone with solipsistic 
inclinations, it is not science.

top_comment.author: Dan Hard

comments.text:
+Dan Hard The short answer is: No. Even the most diffuse of dust in 
interstellar space would be visible to telescopes via infrared signals or 
for the way it blocks the light from stars like nebulae and molecular 
clouds currently do. This is actually one of the many reasons why 
astronomers discovered dark matter in the first place. Galaxies are 
rotating at a speed which doesn't corresponds with the amount of matter 
which is "visible". There's a huge gap in the "matter budget".
And that's because the concentration of matter in between the galaxy is 
really well studied already. There's even "maps" that shows the places with 
higher concentrations of particles. Near our sun for instance, the 
interstellar density is of about 0.07 *atoms/cm3*! Here's one of the maps:
http://www.astronomycafe.net/qadir/LocalBubble.jpg
In short, If the huge *hole* which dark matter currently occupies was just 
diffuse regular matter, it would simply "show up" on the countless of 
studies made by astronomers already :)

+Not Legato yeah, gravity is caused by the presence of matter (and 
ironically for this thread, by the presence of *dark matter* as well).
The big mystery in gravity is that we haven't been able to find the 
force-carrier particle associated with it, similar to how we already found 
the force-carrier of electromagnetism (the photon) and of the Higgs Field 
(the Higgs particle). It is hypothesized that gravity has an associated 
*graviton* particle, but so far everything seems to indicate that gravity 
is the odd, crazy kid in the classroom of standard physics, behaving like 
no one else in class (Similar to dark matter and dark energy)

comments.text:
+Stevo1361
The reason I said beyond all possibility is that, like said, creating a new 
universe is beyond all possibility. We can't ever even know how our own 
universe was born, though we have a strong suspicion.

Creating a universe requires a way to decrease entropy into zero at one 
very small volume in space. Of course, if big bang theory is right, if it's 
not, then I could say anything about flying elephants. Decreasing entropy 
like that just will not happen. It may be possible, but not in the needed 
scale. The energy needed is just so immense. We may once be able to light 
again a couple of stars. But the energy of a star is not even close enough 
to the energy needed for a universe. After all, the energy we put into it, 
is the energy there will always be. Meaning that if we make a universe out 
of the energy of a star, there will never be humankind in that universe.

If any physicist realistically believes in a theory of universes within 
black holes, that physicist is not to be taken seriously. Even if that did 
happen, there is no way to enter another universe. Well, not alive. Not to 
mention that theoretical physics is very strongly quite certain that a 
universe within a black hole is impossible. (And in fact, not all 
physicists even believe in the existence of black holes anymore).

Like I said, if there are other universes, there is no way to get any 
information of them, and there is no way to enter them. Because those 
universes would be universes of their own, and there can't be a connection 
between two different universes.

Imagine the universe has four dimensions. We only perceive three. There 
could be another "3D universe" just two inches from us, but we have no way 
of perceiving it, because we can't perceive four-dimensional space. In 
somewhat a similar way, there may be a separate universe two inches from 
us, but there is no way we can perceive it, because we are bound to our own 
physicality, universe.

And anyway, humankind is too likely to destroy itself before such things 
are relevant to think about. Looking bad already, and no one really wants 
to make a difference.

I wouldn't like to say that it is impossible for humankind to exist 
forever, but I see no realistic reason to believe in such a thing. Yes, 
there may be some spiritual existence, afterlife, but that's not a matter 
of physics. I don't believe that humankind will ever find a way to 
manipulate the fate of the universe. Such energy can't realistically be 
handled.

If we somehow manage to create another big bang, we're doomed. Like I said, 
the time would flow towards the past. And you can easily imagine that it 
will erase not just what has happened, but also all the memories of it. 
Which means that when we start to force the time backwards, we reach the 
very end of our existence. Because once we've got back in time, we would do 
it all again. We would see Galileo and Leonardo again, and we would us 
writing these exactly same comments. And we would have some idealist 
pressing the button which reverses time. And the whole process is going to 
be repeated seemingly infinite times (of course in reality, it's just the 
same time happening again). 

Never try to travel back in time. It's not a good thing.
comments.author: Jesse Heinonen

comments.author: Amsah

comments.text:
+Stevo1361 Yes, it is beyond all possibility to create another universe, 
that would require so much energy that I myself don't believe that it would 
be possible with any realistic technology.

Technically, it might be possible to create another universe if all the 
energy in the universe could be collected and compressed in one single 
point. However, this means that entropy would have to decrease, which means 
that time should have to flow backwards. Well, if time travels backwards, 
it also erases everything that has happened. Creating another big bang 
would be like time traveling to the very beginning.

It is not possible to go from this universe to another universe. Universe 
is, by common definition, the totality of existence, which means that 
everything that exists is in the universe. If we were to enter another 
universe, we would have to step out of our own universe, and because the 
outside of the universe doesn't exist by definition, this is impossible. 

If some sort of stable wormhole existed, and it was possible to go through 
it, it would be possible to enter an area of space were different kinds of 
laws of physics exist. Theoretically. But this area would still be a part 
of our universe, because there is a wormhole between these two areas, and 
that wormhole can't exist outside of any universe.

There may be more universes, but we could never really perceive them, 
because there is no way to exit one universe and enter another, unless 
these "universes" are parts of our universe, in which case they would not 
be separate universes, but simply parts of our universe.

We don't really have much reason to believe that the laws of physics are 
different in one place than in another. However, we can't know that, of 
course, because we cannot perceive the entirety of the universe. However, 
if the growth of entropy applies everywhere, there is no way for any life 
to exist at the time of the heat death of the universe, nor any point 
beyond that.
   Unless of course some religion or religions are correct, but that's a 
matter of religion, and those things can't be described with the laws of 
the physics.

We may exist until the death of the universe, but there is no way any 
technology can ever prevent it. Entropy has to grow in all possible 
situations. This means simply that if humans can build one star, it will 
take enough time that several other stars die. If humans build a planet, 
several planets are destroyed.

The growth of entropy is called time. Time flows forward forever, as the 
entropy grows forever. As long as time flows forward, we can't change the 
fate of the universe. On the other hand, if time flows backward, and 
entropy decreases, then we would go backwards too, our experiences will be 
erased and so on. If time stops, there is no change we could make.

There is no way humankind could stop the death of the universe.

comments.text:
There is quite an accurate answer to your question.
Before the beginning of the Universe existed nothing, or empty 
higher-dimensional space. It was a perfect phase of nothingness. From 0 to 
10^-43 seconds is known as the Planck Epoch. At the Plank energy (10^19 
eV), the gravitational force was as strong as the other quantum forces, 
resulting in a probable unification of all forces, a single force denoted 
as the "super force". This resulted in a perfect symmetry. At 10^-43 
seconds after begun the creation of the embryonic universe. This occurred 
due to a breakage in the super-force due to a random quantum fluctuation. 
Gravity, broke from the super-force, causing a quake through out the whole 
universe. the other three forces were still unified, they are denoted as a 
smaller symmetry known as GUT symmetry. This is called the GUT era. (Temp = 
10^32 C) After 10^-34 seconds the strong force broke from the GUT, 
resulting in the end of the inflationary period, and transitioned into a 
common friedmann expansion. The universe consisted of many particles, at 
10^27 degrees the gluons, quarks and leptons condensed into baryonic 
matter, and such. This is important in giving you an image of the Universe. 
The universe has defined borders not in terms of the observers within the 
universe, but the observers outside the universe. This universe is an 
embryo of unlimited space-time, space can be stretched infinitely, and you 
can travel in it infinitely without ever reaching the end, because you are 
the observer. 

If it is flat, it only means that if you construct a triangle with three 
straight line segments where all end points are in contact with another, 
the angles inside the triangle equate to 180 degrees, the shape of the 
universe doesn't particularly mean much, when asking what is beyond. What 
is beyond is theorized to be a perfect phase of nothingness. Nothingness 
just waiting for a random quantum fluctuation.

comments.text:
+Barujin Anon
The video actually articulates the issue with that.  Dark energy becomes 
more powerful as the universe gets bigger, so it's a positive-feedback 
loop.  If the universe were contracting, then it could be possible for 
gravity to overtake dark energy, but the reverse is true.  What's more, it 
doesn't matter if we have more black holes or what, all matter has gravity 
and that can not change over time.  The only thing that matters for the 
strength of gravity is proximity between objects, and that's getting 
further.  So gravity is pulling back "in" less and dark energy is putting 
"out" more over time.  That paints a very clear picture.  Again, this could 
be wrong, but only in ways we haven't discovered yet.
comments.author: Dgfrmxon

comments.author: CBebop 4Ever

comments.text:
I think you're using outdated sources.  Dark energy was only really 
substantiated and popularized around 2000.  Lots of sources before then go 
into the dichotomy of "closed universe" and "open universe".  Some even 
talked about bouncing universes.

Bouncing universes are not possible.  There is no room in the 2nd law for 
something like that to happen.  A closed universe is also extremely 
implausible with what we've learned about dark energy.

You could imagine that dark energy will stop and reverse itself.  But 
that's all you're doing - imagining.  Such a proposition isn't based in 
anything real.  All the real physics points to an open universe... at least 
right now.  In this field we are constantly greeted with new surprises, so 
we're cautious about saying this definitely.  Nonetheless, if the universe 
does re-contract, it won't be a simple or single revision to the laws as we 
know them today.

assume we are wrong when our theory does not match with experiment, which 
leads to much less frustration and confusion.

same, a physicist wouldn't say that one set of physical laws was at work in 
China and a second set of physical laws existed in Canada. Rather the 
hypothesis that was used to test these two experiments was incorrect.

exponential speed. What is actually happening is, due to the growth of the 
universe, and because universe is the space of itself, the universe isn't 
expanding somewhere, it's expanding in itself. Which makes matter shrink!
If something in a distance shrinks, it would look like it was moving apart,

would actually look like it was accelerating at an exponential rate.

would narrow because we can only view what exists in a 3-dimensional space, 
thus making things grow and grow (they would look like they were coming to 
us exponentially slower).

captions.text: Looking up at the night sky,
we are amazed by how it seems to go on forever.
But what will the sky look like
billions of years from now?
A particular type of scientist,
called a cosmologist,
spends her time thinking about that very question.
The end of the universe is intimately linked
to what the universe contains.
Over 100 years ago,
Einstein developed the Theory of General Relativity,
formed of equations that help us
understand the relationship
between what a universe is made of
and its shape.
It turns out that the universe
could be curved like a ball or sphere.
We call this positively curved or closed.
Or it could be shaped like a saddle.
We call this negatively curved or open.
Or it could be flat.
And that shape determines

We now know that the universe is very close to flat.
However, the components of the universe

We can predict how the universe

So, what is the universe made of?
The universe contains all the things that we can see,
like stars, gas, and planets.
We call these things ordinary or baryonic matter.
Even though we see them all around us,
the total energy density of these components
is actually very small,
around 5% of the total energy of the universe.
So, now let's talk about what the other 95% is.
Just under 27% of the rest
of the energy density of the universe
is made up of what we call dark matter.
Dark matter is only very weakly interacting with light,
which means it doesn't shine or reflect light
in the way that stars and planets do,
but, in every other way,
it behaves like ordinary matter --
it attracts things gravitationally.
In fact, the only way we can detect this dark matter

how things orbit around it

as it curves the space around it.
We have yet to discover a dark matter particle,

But this still doesn't add up to 100%.
The remaining 68%
of the energy density of the universe

This dark energy doesn't behave
like any other substance we know at all
and acts more like anti-gravity force.
We say that it has a gravitational pressure,
which ordinary matter and dark matter do not.
Instead of pulling the universe together,
as we would expect gravity to do,
the universe appears to be expanding apart

The leading idea for dark energy
is that it is a cosmological constant.
That means it has the strange property
that it expands as the volume of space increases
to keep its energy density constant.
So, as the universe expands
as it is doing right now,
there will be more and more dark energy.
Dark matter and baryonic matter,
on the other hand,
don't expand with the universe
and become more diluted.
Because of this property
of the cosmological constant,

Eventually, the universe will run out of gas

Given enough time,
even these black holes will evaporate,

That is what we call the heat death of the universe.
While it might sound depressing
living in a universe

and devoid of life,
the end fate of our universe
actually has a beautiful symmetry
to its hot, fiery beginning.
We call the accelerating end state

So, the universe will end
